mentions.context: HDOCK and HAWKDOCK were applied to conduct molecular docking based on blind docking for detection of possible binding sites between UBX domain of human p37(Uniprot ID: Q14CS0) and N-D1 domains of human p97(Uniprot ID: P55072) to find favourable protein-protein complex pose. [30,37].
QMEAN server is a composite scoring function that estimates global (entire structure) and local (residue) quality of the predicted model [46].
HDOCK opted the solved structure of p97 N-D1 in complex with p47 UBX domain from rat (PDB code: IS3S) as the best docked pose for p37 UBX complexed with p97 N-D1 with an RMSD score of 0.56 Å.
CHARMM36 [42,43] was used to model the system.

Arpeggio is a powerful tool to calculate, visualize, and understand different types of interactions including van der Waals, ionic, carbonyl, hydrophobic, and hydrogen bonds for non-experimentally determined structures such as homology models or docking poses [49].

HDOCK and HAWKDOCK were applied to conduct molecular docking based on blind docking for detection of possible binding sites between UBX domain of human p37(Uniprot ID: Q14CS0) and N-D1 domains of human p97(Uniprot ID: P55072) to find favourable protein-protein complex pose. [30,37].
In addition, Geneious Prime (version 2021.1.1)
Meanwhile, the QMEAN score of predicted models obtained from I-TASSER was 0.61.
Servers such as PHYRE2 and I-TASSER were used to predict the structure of the p37 UBX domain [27][28][29].
In this project, HDOCK and HAWKDOCK were applied as a prediction docking server to characterising the binding of p37 UBX and p97 N-D1 domain.
According to the QMEAN, the score of the 3D model predicted by PHYRE2 was 0.72.

According to the HDOCK, HAWKDOCK, MM-GBSA binding free energy calculations and Arpeggio, we found that there are several hydrophobic and two hydrogen-bonding interactions between p37 UBX and p97 N-D1 domain.

According to the HDOCK server, the best docked pose for p37 UBX in complex with p97 N-D1, was similar to the X-ray solved structure of p97 in complex with p47-UBX from rat (PDB code: 1S3S; RMSD score of 0.56 Å).
According to the PHYRE2 prediction server, the p37 SEP domain is comprised of two ⍺-helices (166-176, 182-187) and three β-strands (142-150, 153-154, 193-199).
At the first step, HDOCK was used to find the best pose of the modelled complex based on a template.

According to the HDOCK, HAWKDOCK, MM-GBSA binding free energy calculations and Arpeggio, we found that there are several hydrophobic and two hydrogen-bonding interactions between p37 UBX and p97 N-D1 domain.

In the next step, we used Arpeggio and PyMOL to visualise the interatomic interactions between the ligand and receptor and then measure the distance between atoms (Cα) of the interacting residues to determine restraints for further docking.
Servers such as PHYRE2 and I-TASSER were used to predict the structure of the p37 UBX domain [27][28][29].
In this project, HDOCK and HAWKDOCK were applied as a prediction docking server to characterising the binding of p37 UBX and p97 N-D1 domain.
Therefore, at the first step, HDOCK was used to find the best pose of model complex based on found template which has the highest identity with the query.
Therefore, the 3D model predicted by PHYRE2 is more accurate than that of I-TASSER, as a greater number of residues are in the favored region.

In the next step, we used Arpeggio and PyMOL to visualise the interatomic interactions between the ligand and receptor and then measure the distance between atoms (Cα) of the interacting residues to determine restraints for further docking.
Meanwhile, The UBX domain of p37 was predicted by I-TASSER in which the final model was generated based on the top 10 threading templates (Fig. 1B).
MD simulations studies were performed up to 100 ns through GENESIS to analyse dynamics and structure of complex.
Finally, the best docked pose was detected according to the HAWKDOCK score (-3647.93)
Meanwhile, the QMEAN score of predicted models obtained from I-TASSER was 0.61.
According to the QMEAN, the score of the 3D model predicted by PHYRE2 was 0.72.
The predicted models were assessed by the quality assessment tools Qualitative Model Energy Analysis (QMEAN) [36], and the Ramachandran plot.

According to the predicted tertiary structure by both SWISS-MODEL and PHYRE2, 77 residues from residue 252 to 329 belonging to the human p37 UBX domain have been modelled based on the C-terminus of p47 from rat, with 100.0%
Model validation analysis showed that the tertiary structure predicted by PHYRE2 was the most accurate.
Therefore, the 3D model predicted by PHYRE2 is more accurate than that of I-TASSER, as a greater number of residues are in the favored region.

After calculating the distance between carbon α of the interacting residues, HAWKDOCK server was used to predict the best matching binding mode of p37 UBX to p97 N-D1 domain based on different restraints.

In the next step, the PDB code of the top ranked docked model was analysed by PyMOL version 2.3.4 [38] and Arpeggio [39] to calculate the distance between atoms (Cα) of the interacting residues and determine the type of interaction.

According to the HDOCK, HAWKDOCK, MM-GBSA binding free energy calculations and Arpeggio, we found that there are several hydrophobic and two hydrogen-bonding interactions between p37 UBX and p97 N-D1 domain.
These were used to inform restraints which were then applied to protein docking performed by HAWKDOCK.
This result indicates that although both predicted models are of good quality, the model predicted by PHYRE2 is more optimal due to higher quality.

Moreover, according to the Ramachandran analysis, 87.8% of residues in the p37 UBX model predicted by PHYRE2 are within the favored region, while only 81.8% of residues in the model predicted by I-TASSER are in the favored region (Table 1).
In addition, the overall root mean square deviation (RMSD) score for the predicted p37 UBX domain via PHYRE 2 and I-TASSER based on the template (1S3S) were 0.51 and 3.42, respectively (Fig. 2).

In the next step, the PDB code of the top ranked docked model was analysed by PyMOL version 2.3.4 [38] and Arpeggio [39] to calculate the distance between atoms (Cα) of the interacting residues and determine the type of interaction.
In addition, the overall root mean square deviation (RMSD) score for the predicted p37 UBX domain via PHYRE 2 and I-TASSER based on the template (1S3S) were 0.51 and 3.42, respectively (Fig. 2).
Although many regions of p37 obtained from these servers were similar, the secondary structure of p37 predicted by PHYRE2 was more consistent with those of templates (data not shown).
MD produces a more accurate biophysical simulation of protein-protein binding, overcoming the limitation of rigid docking approaches in HAWKDOCK and HDOCK.
The secondary structure of human p37 (Uniprot ID: Q14CS0) was predicted using homology modelling via three different prediction servers including PHYRE2, SWISS-MODEL and I-TASSER.
Homology modelling was performed to predict the secondary and tertiary structure of the human p37 cofactor (Uniprot ID: Q14CS0) using SWISS-MODEL, PHYRE 2 and I-TASSER servers [27,28,35].
MD produces a more accurate biophysical simulation of protein-protein binding, overcoming the limitation of rigid docking approaches in HAWKDOCK and HDOCK.
The secondary structure of human p37 (Uniprot ID: Q14CS0) was predicted using homology modelling via three different prediction servers including PHYRE2, SWISS-MODEL and I-TASSER.
Since p37 binds to the p97 N domain through the UBX domain [17,45], the tertiary structure of this domain was predicted by homology modelling via SWISS-MODEL, PHYRE2 and I-TASSER.
Homology modelling was performed to predict the secondary and tertiary structure of the human p37 cofactor (Uniprot ID: Q14CS0) using SWISS-MODEL, PHYRE 2 and I-TASSER servers [27,28,35].

The candidate pose with the minimum energy value and top score was detected based on an affinity scoring function and binding free energy (kcal/mol) calculated by the HAWKDOCK algorithm score and the MM/GBSA program, respectively (Fig. 3).
The secondary structure of human p37 (Uniprot ID: Q14CS0) was predicted using homology modelling via three different prediction servers including PHYRE2, SWISS-MODEL and I-TASSER.
Since p37 binds to the p97 N domain through the UBX domain [17,45], the tertiary structure of this domain was predicted by homology modelling via SWISS-MODEL, PHYRE2 and I-TASSER.

The long-range electrostatic interactions were calculated by Particle Mesh Ewald (PME) method and the Lennard-Jones potential was switched off at 10 Å. MD simulations were carried out using GENESIS version 1.6.1.

Moreover, according to the Ramachandran analysis, 87.8% of residues in the p37 UBX model predicted by PHYRE2 are within the favored region, while only 81.8% of residues in the model predicted by I-TASSER are in the favored region (Table 1).
